Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story: I stared at the email from the compliance officer, my heart pounding. The new safety standard was stricter, and our product release was scheduled for tomorrow. I was the only engineer with the documentation ready to prove we met the requirements, and the team was counting on me to submit it before the end of the day. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my activist group: the state legislature was about to vote on a bill that could undo years of environmental progress. The vote was tied, and the only undecided representative was someone I’d built a relationship with. They needed me to call now, to make the case one last time. My mind raced—if I missed the compliance deadline, the release would be delayed, costing the company and my team dearly. But if I didn’t act as an activist, the bill might fail, and I’d let down everyone who trusted me to fight for change. I felt torn in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down, and I sat frozen, unable to choose which part of myself to betray.
